rules.rule_text_en: Use good (adjective) before a noun; use well (adverb) after a verb for how someone does something. Use well with past participles (well-known, well-paid).
rules.rule_text_uk: Good — прикметник (перед іменником); well — прислівник (після дієслова), коли описуємо, як щось роблять. Well також уживається з дієприкметниками: well-known, well-paid.
rules.rule_short_en: good = adjective; well = adverb / past participle
rules.rule_short_uk: good = прикметник; well = прислівник / з дієприкметником

rules.rule_text_en: Fast, hard and late can be adjectives or adverbs. With work/try, hard means 'with a lot of effort' (work hard).
rules.rule_text_uk: Fast, hard і late можуть бути прикметниками або прислівниками. Hard із work/try означає «з великим зусиллям» (work hard).
rules.rule_short_en: fast/hard/late can be adjective or adverb
rules.rule_short_uk: fast/hard/late можуть бути прикм. або присл.

rules.rule_text_en: Hardly means 'very little / almost not'. It usually goes before the verb (hardly know). Hard and hardly have different meanings.
rules.rule_text_uk: Hardly означає «дуже мало / майже ні». Зазвичай стоїть перед дієсловом (hardly know). Hard і hardly мають різні значення.

rules.rule_text_en: Late = not on time. Lately = recently. Don’t confuse them (late ≠ lately).
rules.rule_text_uk: Late = «не вчасно». Lately = «останнім часом». Не плутайте: late ≠ lately.
rules.rule_short_en: late = not on time; lately = recently
rules.rule_short_uk: late = не вчасно; lately = останнім часом

rules.rule_text_en: Use so + adjective/adverb (so cold, so quickly).
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте so + прикметник/прислівник: so cold, so quickly.

rules.rule_text_en: Use such + (a/an) + adjective + noun: such a nice day, such good news.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте such + (a/an) + прикметник + іменник: such a nice day, such good news.

rules.rule_text_en: Use so much/many/little/few + noun: so much work, so many people, so little time, so few seats.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте so much/many/little/few + іменник: so much work, so many people, so little time, so few seats.
examples: We have so much to do.

rules.rule_text_en: So/such can be followed by that to show result: It was so late that we went home. It was such a mess that we stopped.
rules.rule_text_uk: So/such можуть поєднуватися з that, щоб показати наслідок: It was so late that… / It was such a mess that…
examples: It was so hot that we stayed inside.
It was such a long queue that we left.

rules.rule_text_en: Enough usually comes after an adjective/adverb: warm enough, speak loudly enough.
rules.rule_text_uk: Enough зазвичай стоїть після прикметника/прислівника: warm enough, speak loudly enough.

rules.rule_text_en: Enough comes before a noun: enough money, enough time. Use not enough + noun for lack.
rules.rule_text_uk: Enough стоїть перед іменником: enough money, enough time. Для нестачі: not enough + іменник.

rules.rule_text_en: Too means 'more than is good/necessary': too hot, too quickly. Use too much/many with nouns.
rules.rule_text_uk: Too означає «забагато / більше, ніж потрібно»: too hot, too quickly. З іменниками: too much/many.

rules.rule_text_en: Use too … to and (not) … enough to: too tired to work; not old enough to drive.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте too … to та (not) … enough to: too tired to work; not old enough to drive.
examples: I was too late to catch the bus.
He isn’t experienced enough to lead it.

rules.rule_text_en: Pretty and fairly mean 'to a moderate degree' and are common in spoken English: pretty tired, fairly easy.
rules.rule_text_uk: Pretty і fairly означають «досить / помірно» і часто вживаються в розмовній мові: pretty tired, fairly easy.

rules.rule_text_en: Quite can mean 'fairly' (quite nice) or 'completely' with some adjectives (quite certain). Context matters.
rules.rule_text_uk: Quite може означати «досить» (quite nice) або «повністю» з деякими прикметниками (quite certain). Значення залежить від контексту.

rules.rule_text_en: Rather often suggests something negative or surprising: rather cold, rather strange. It can also soften criticism.
rules.rule_text_uk: Rather часто має відтінок негативу або несподіванки: rather cold, rather strange. Також може пом’якшувати критику.

rules.rule_text_en: Rather/quite can be used with a/an: rather a good idea, quite a long time. Word order matters.
rules.rule_text_uk: Rather/quite можна вживати з a/an: rather a good idea, quite a long time. Важливий порядок слів.

rules.rule_text_en: Form the comparative with -er (cheap→cheaper) or more (expensive→more expensive). Use than to compare.
rules.rule_text_uk: Порівняльний ступінь: -er (cheap→cheaper) або more (expensive→more expensive). Для порівняння вживайте than.
examples: This phone is cheaper than mine.
Today is more humid than yesterday.

rules.rule_text_en: Spelling changes: big→bigger, easy→easier, hot→hotter. Some adjectives are irregular (good→better).
rules.rule_text_uk: Правопис: big→bigger, easy→easier, hot→hotter. Деякі прикметники неправильні (good→better).
examples: A car is bigger than a bike.

rules.rule_text_en: Use comparative + than, or comparative without than when the comparison is clear from context.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте comparative + than, або comparative без than, якщо порівняння зрозуміле з контексту.
examples: I expected it to be cheaper.
Her new job is better than the old one.

rules.rule_text_en: Use much/far/a lot + comparative for big differences: much better, far more expensive.
rules.rule_text_uk: Використовуйте much/far/a lot + comparative для великої різниці: much better, far more expensive.

rules.rule_text_en: Use a bit/a little/slightly + comparative for small differences: a bit older, slightly cheaper.
rules.rule_text_uk: Для невеликої різниці: a bit/a little/slightly + comparative: a bit older, slightly cheaper.

rules.rule_text_en: Use any/no + comparative in questions/negatives: any better? no longer. Also: not any bigger.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте any/no + comparative у питаннях і запереченнях: any better? not any bigger. Також: no longer.

rules.rule_text_en: After than you can use object pronoun or clause: than me / than I am. Both are common; choose consistently.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після than можливий займенник-об’єкт або підрядна частина: than me / than I am. Обидва варіанти можливі — дотримуйтеся одного стилю.

rules.rule_text_en: Use comparative + and + comparative for change (better and better). Use the + comparative, the + comparative (the sooner, the better).
rules.rule_text_uk: Для змін: comparative + and + comparative (better and better). Також: the + comparative, the + comparative (the sooner, the better).
rules.rule_short_en: better and better / the sooner, the better
rules.rule_short_uk: better and better / the sooner, the better
examples: The more you practise, the better you get.

rules.rule_text_en: Use as + adjective/adverb + as to show equality: as tall as, as quickly as.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте as + прикметник/прислівник + as для рівності: as tall as, as quickly as.
examples: My bag is as heavy as yours.
He ran as fast as he could.

rules.rule_text_en: Use not as/so … as for inequality: not as big as, not so expensive as.
rules.rule_text_uk: Для нерівності: not as/so … as: not as big as, not so expensive as.
examples: This room isn’t as bright as the other one.
It’s not so simple as it seems.

rules.rule_text_en: Use as much/many as with nouns: as much time as, as many people as. Also: as little/few as.
rules.rule_text_uk: З іменниками: as much/many as (as much time as, as many people as), також as little/few as.
examples: I don’t have as much time as you.
There weren’t as many guests as expected.

rules.rule_text_en: Use than after comparatives. Don’t use than after as … as.
rules.rule_text_uk: Після порівняльного ступеня вживайте than. Після as … as than не використовується.
examples: He’s as tall as his dad.

rules.rule_text_en: Form superlatives with -est or most: the cheapest, the most interesting. Use the with superlatives.
rules.rule_text_uk: Найвищий ступінь: -est або most: the cheapest, the most interesting. Зазвичай потрібен the.

rules.rule_text_en: Spelling changes: big→the biggest, easy→the easiest. Some are irregular: good→the best, bad→the worst.
rules.rule_text_uk: Правопис: big→the biggest, easy→the easiest. Є неправильні: good→the best, bad→the worst.

rules.rule_text_en: Use in/of with superlatives: the tallest in the class; the best of the three options.
rules.rule_text_uk: З найвищим ступенем: in/of — the tallest in the class; the best of the three options.
examples: She’s the fastest in our team.
This is the cheapest of the three.

rules.rule_text_en: Use one of the + superlative + plural noun: one of the most exciting films.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте one of the + найвищий ступінь + множина: one of the most exciting films.
examples: It’s one of the oldest buildings here.
He’s one of the best players.

rules.rule_text_en: Use superlative + ever for lifetime experience: the best meal I’ve ever had.
rules.rule_text_uk: Вживайте superlative + ever для досвіду за все життя: the best meal I’ve ever had.
examples: It was the funniest thing I’ve ever seen.
This is the hardest test I’ve ever done.

rules.rule_text_en: Word order is usually: subject + verb + object. Don’t put the object before the verb in statements.
rules.rule_text_uk: Порядок слів зазвичай: підмет + присудок + додаток. У ствердженнях додаток не ставлять перед дієсловом.

rules.rule_text_en: When you have place and time, place usually comes before time: I met her in Kyiv yesterday.
rules.rule_text_uk: Коли є місце й час, зазвичай спершу місце, потім час: I met her in Kyiv yesterday.
examples: We stayed at home all evening.
I saw him at the station this morning.

rules.rule_text_en: With verbs of movement (go, come, travel), place is important and comes after the verb: go to work, travel abroad. Then add time.
rules.rule_text_uk: З дієсловами руху (go, come, travel) місце важливе й стоїть після дієслова: go to work, travel abroad. Потім можна додати час.
examples: She went to the doctor yesterday.
They travelled to Spain last year.

rules.rule_text_en: Adverbs like always/usually/often go before the main verb: I often work from home.
rules.rule_text_uk: Прислівники частоти (always/usually/often) стоять перед основним дієсловом: I often work from home.

rules.rule_text_en: With the verb be, adverbs go after be: She is always polite.
rules.rule_text_uk: З дієсловом be прислівник стоїть після be: She is always polite.

rules.rule_text_en: With auxiliary verbs, adverbs usually go after the first auxiliary: I have never been there.
rules.rule_text_uk: З допоміжними дієсловами прислівник зазвичай після першого допоміжного: I have never been there.

rules.rule_text_en: Some adverbs can go at the end, especially manner/time: She spoke quietly. We met again yesterday.
rules.rule_text_uk: Деякі прислівники часто стоять у кінці (особливо способу/часу): She spoke quietly. We met again yesterday.

rules.rule_text_en: Just/already/still usually go in mid position (near the verb/aux): I’m still waiting. I’ve just finished.
rules.rule_text_uk: Just/already/still зазвичай стоять у середині речення (біля дієслова/aux): I’m still waiting. I’ve just finished.
